But one can observe the weak
and the despairing tearing off their clothes
and pulling out their hair.

62. Lucas van Leyden, with his sharp
expert burin, artfully engraved
David playing on his harp before Saul–
indeed, represented for us so naturally
the agitated appearance of Saul,
but concerning those wracked by
inner fear, they should be deathly pale,
reaching out their arms as if fleeing.
right-middleExample of Lucas van Leyden, in depicting agitation.

63. In Rome there is piece by the Tuscan Giotto
made of inlaid glazed stones,
so that it will not easily decay, called Mosaic.
Already as it was painted, it could not be scorned:
in a ship buffeted by storms,
there one sees, excellently portrayed,
a terrified amazement among the Apostles
as Christ walked on the Sea at night.
right-middleExample by Giotto of depicting terror.

64. There one sees as Peter, stepping outside the bark
as summoned, fearful of the wind and high water,
begins to sink at the feet of the Lord,
as if he were almost drowning.
One also saw in earlier times a frightened dismay
in a piece in which were painted
Amphitrion the King with Alcmene,
Mother of Hercules, who appeared full of fear.

65. Seeing the young Hercules in the Cradle
prove his strength by strangling
two fierce snakes with mighty pressure,
seeming in the midst of this horrible spectacle,
the Motherly heart, full of fear and worry.
But whose work this was, should not be hidden,
It was Zeuxis, painter from Heraclea.
In painting the emotions, no one was more generous.

66. Then there was Parrhasius of Ephesus,
who first began to consider
the outward forms of the Face,
and the movements; yet Aristides
was wonderfully gifted in this,
as was told earlier. While his body is already
buried and his work is no more to be found,
Death has not devoured his fame.

67. He also depicted disturbances of the mind:
in a City taken by the enemy
a small Child, innocently feeding,
grasps at his Mother’s wound
right-middleExample: how the pain of death was depicted, as well as worry and fear.
